FAQ.question: Why is an Occupancy Certificate required in Maharashtra?
FAQ.answer: It confirms that the building is legally approved, structurally safe, and compliant with municipal norms, making it lawful for residents to occupy.

FAQ.question: Is OC mandatory for resale or registration of property?
FAQ.answer: While transactions may still occur, absence of OC can lead to legal risks, utility issues, and loan rejections.

FAQ.question: How is OC different from Completion Certificate (CC)?
FAQ.answer: CC confirms construction is completed; OC confirms the building is safe and approved for occupation after all compliance checks.

FAQ.question: Does an OC guarantee that the project is RERA approved?
FAQ.answer: No. RERA registration is separate. OC confirms completion compliance, while RERA ensures project registration and transparency.

FAQ.question: Can a building without OC face penalties?
FAQ.answer: Yes. Occupying or selling units without OC may invite legal action, restricted utilities, or demolition in severe violations.

FAQ.question: Is OC needed to apply for bank loans or home registration?
FAQ.answer: Banks and legal teams prefer OC for completed projects to verify compliance before loan approval.

FAQ.question: Does OC verify land title or ownership?
FAQ.answer: No. It validates building compliance, not title. Ownership must be verified via Sale Deed, EC, and Property Card.

FAQ.question: Does OC include fire, sewage, and utility approvals?
FAQ.answer: Yes. OC is issued only after safety, firefighting, sewage, road access, and utility permissions are cleared.

FAQ.question: Can OC be issued partially for some wings or phases?
FAQ.answer: Yes. In phased developments, OC may be granted wing-wise or block-wise until full completion.

FAQ.question: Is OC data from JaaGa authentic?
FAQ.answer: Yes. All records are sourced directly from municipal and authority databases without modification.
